title: Welcome
text:
Welcome to this brief introduction to Bioinformatics. It is intended as an introduction to this field and to lay the foundation for the mostly complex and individual analyses.
The contents of this website are for informational purposes only. They are continuously updated and expanded. However, no guarantee can be given for the topicality, correctness, and completeness of the information provided.
If you have any questions or comments, please contact me at: joerg.wennmann@julius-kuehn.de

title: Welcome
text:
Required items
To complete this tutorial, you will need access to a Galaxy Platform. There are various Galaxy servers in different regions around the world. Of course, you are free to choose whichever instance you prefer. For this tutorial, I recommend creating an account at usegalaxy.eu. Accounts are free and can be deleted at any time.

Required course items The follwoing course items are required:

Bring your own laptop
Internet connection
An account at usegalaxy.eu

title: Welcome
text:
Crate an Galaxy account
Depending on the instance and update of the website, the home page may look slightly different.

Login or Register to Galaxy

Open your favorite browser.
Browse to https://usegalaxy.eu
Login or register


If you have registered as a new user, don‚Äôt forget to confirm your email address.

title: Welcome
text:
Laptop or computer
There are no requirements for your laptop! You can use any laptop or computer to participate, as all calculations are performed on the Galaxy server itself.

title: Welcome
text:
Internet connection.
A stable internet connection is required, as a connection to the Galaxy server is necessary in order to perform bioinformatic analysis.

title: Welcome
text:
Websites

Galaxy Training Network https://training.galaxyproject.org

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
To get started with the Galaxy platform, complete the following tutorial. It takes about 40 minutes and will familiarize you with the interface and the most important Galaxy terms. You will also upload your first data.

First steps with Galaxy
Go through and finish the tutiral ‚ÄúA short introduction to Galaxy‚Äù!
The tutorial is available in several languages:
 Galaxy Introduction Tutorial (GTN)
 Galaxy Introduction Tutorial (GTN, automatic translation)

Reference This tutorial is from the Galaxy Training Network (GTN): Introduction to Galaxy Lizenz: CC BY 4.0.

text:

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Starting with training data
Once the tutorial is complete, we can begin with our own data. I hope you enjoy it.

 Let‚Äôs get started!

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Create a new history
Now that the tutorial is complete, we can plan the work with our own data. To do this, we create a new, empty history. Then we rename the history to Data NCBI

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Rename the new history
After creating the new history, we rename it. With the new name, it can be clearly identified and cannot be confused with previous analyses.

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Download sequencing data
The sequence data that provided here is taken from one of my publications and is intended to serve as an example. The sequence data has been published on NCBI SRA and is freely available. The sequenced sample is a large dsDNA virus and the data is small in size. The small size makes it perfect, easy and quick to handle.

Reference



Isolate
BioSample
NCBI SRA (Illumina)
NCBI SRA (Nanopore)




BmNPV-My
SAMN18849911
SRR14313723
SRR26992684



Wennmann, J.T., Lim, F.S., Senger, S., Gani, M., Jehle, J.A., Keilwagen, J (2024). Haplotype determination of the Bombyx mori nucleopolyhedrovirus by Nanopore sequencing and linkage of single nucleotide variants. Journal of General Virology. 105 (5), 001983. [https://doi.org/10.1099/jgv.0.001983]

Please download the sequence data directly and save it temporarily on your computer. We will then upload it directly to your newly created Galaxy history ‚ÄúData NCBI.‚Äù

Downloading sequencing data

Follow this link to download the Illumina data and save it on your computer. You should download the forward and reverse reads in two separate files:
üíæ [Illumina forward reads]
üíæ [Illumina reverse reads]
Follow the link to download the Nanopore reads:
üíæ [Nanopore reads]


You should now have three files saved on your computer.

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Upload your data to Galaxy
Sequence data is usually obtained directly in fastq or fastqsanger format. It is then uploaded to the Galaxy platform. We will do this in the next step.

Upload your data to Galaxy

You have the three files.

Go to the folder where you saved the files.

Go to usegalaxy.eu and click on ‚ÄúUpload.‚Äù

Drag your files into the upload window (drag and drop).

Click on ‚ÄúStart.‚Äù The upload will begin.

Once all files have been uploaded, click on ‚ÄúClose.‚Äù


Now you have to wait until all files are completely uploaded. This may take a moment. The upload is complete when the files appear green in the history.

title: Getting started with Galaxy
section: Status of files in your history
text:
Status of files in your history
Files can have four statuses in your history. Only green files and files being processed can be worked on further.








Color
Status
Meaning




üü© Green
Ready
File is ready to use


üüß Orange
Running/Processing
File is being processed (job still running)


‚¨ú Gray
Queued
File is waiting to run


üü• Red
Error
File has failed (an error occurred)

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Run your first Galaxy tools
Once the data has been uploaded, we want to do something with it. We want to analyse it, not just look at it. But before we analyse it, it‚Äôs important that we get to know the data well. It‚Äôs important to know whether the sequencing worked well. We also want to know how good the quality of the sequencing is.
There are two tools we can use for Illumina and Nanopore data.

Practice tool selection
Please practice to select some tools. Go to web interface of usegalaxy.eu and click on tools. In the tools menu you can search for tools you would like to apply to your data. Please search for two tools and select them:

falco
nanoplot

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Quality check of Nanopore reads
At first we start the tool nanoplot on the Nanopore data. The file‚Äôs name should be SRR26992684_nanopore.fastqsanger.gz and it is the input for the tool nanoplot.

Start tool nanoplot on Nanopore data

title: Getting started with Galaxy
text:
Quality check of Illumina reads
Next, we use the falco tool, which we run on the forward file of the Illumina data. Here we chose the file SRR14313726_forward_illumina.fastqsanger.gz.

Start tool falco on Illumina data

title: Getting started with Galaxy
section: The correct files for the right tools
text:
The correct files for the right tools
Not all files can be read, processed or analysed by all tools. You learn this over time and with increasing experience.

Chose the correct file!
A common mistake is selecting the wrong files for the wrong tool. Falco is for short reads (Illumina data) and Nanoplot is for long reads. Therefore, the following combination must be selected:

falco = SRR14313726_forward_illumina.fastqsanger.gz

falco = SRR14313726_reverse_illumina.fastqsanger.gz
nanoplot = SRR26992684_nanopore.fastqsanger.gz

title: Getting started with Galaxy
section: Reviewing the output and evaluating the quality
text:
Reviewing the output and evaluating the quality
To view the results of the tools, click on the eye icon next to the outputs. Make sure you select the correct output files. They are called html report for the nanoplot tool and webpage for the falco tool.

Let‚Äôs discuss the results together!
Click on the eye of one of the files. The results should open in the center panel.


 The results are discussed together in the group.

Self-study to interpret the results
If you would like to learn how to evaluate and analyse the output of falco (or fastqc, which is the predecessor of falco) and nanoplot yourself, you can do so in the following tutorial:
Galaxy Training Tutorial - Quality Control.
Enjoy reading!

title: Where is the raw sequencing data stored publicly?
text:
Most peer-reviewed journals require studies dealing with bioinformatic data to include a data availability statement. This statement explains where the raw sequencing data and all important associated data sets are available. Publishing sequence data online is now mandatory and considered good practice, as it allows other scientists to repeat the analyses or use the data for their own studies.

Typically, the Data Availability Statement is located at the end of the manuscript. Sometimes it is also located at the very beginning. The information can also be integrated into the Materials and Methods section.

title: Where is the raw sequencing data stored publicly?
text:
Most peer-reviewed journals require studies dealing with bioinformatic data to include a data availability statement. This statement explains where the raw sequencing data and all important associated data sets are available. Publishing sequence data online is now mandatory and considered good practice, as it allows other scientists to repeat the analyses or use the data for their own studies.

Typically, the Data Availability Statement is located at the end of the manuscript. Sometimes it is also located at the very beginning. The information can also be integrated into the Materials and Methods section.

title: Where is the raw sequencing data stored publicly?
text:
Sequence Read Archive (SRA)
Sequence data is published as raw data. The world‚Äôs largest public database for raw sequence data from high-throughput sequencing is the Sequence Read Archive (SRA). The SRA was founded in 2007 and is now jointly operated by the NCBI (USA), the EBI/ENA (Europe), and the DDBJ (Japan).
The SRA is the world‚Äôs largest collection of sequence data.

Visit the Sequence Read Archive (SRA)

Visit https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra
Search for SRA data entry SRR14313721

 Next, you should see the SRA record entry.
What information can you see?
Can you find out the meaning of‚Ä¶

BioProject
BioSample
Run

title: Where is the raw sequencing data stored publicly?
text:
SRA entry information
The SRA offers the possibility to retrieve a lot of information about the sequencing. We will look at this in the next step. To do this, we click directly on the run entry SRR14313721.

SRA entry up close
Click on SRR14313721.

This should open the detailed view, which provides information on the number of sequenced bases, the quality of the sequencing, and the format of the sequence data.

title: Where is the raw sequencing data stored publicly?
text:
Taxonomy Analysis Tool
The SRA web interface also offers a simple analysis of the taxonomy. This is helpful if you want to know what is included in the sequencing. It can provide an indication of whether there may be contamination in the sequencing.

Taxonomy Analysis Tool - Window into the SRA dataset
At the bottom, there is a field called ‚ÄòView in Krona‚Äô, which we click on.
 The Taxonomy Browser window will then open. This analysis is performed automatically by NCBI SRA for every dataset that is uploaded there. It is a rough metagenomic analysis based on the information stored at NCBI itself. You can see which organisms (including viruses) were found in the sequence data.
 The web interface also offers an interactive way to analyse the composition. This tool is called Krona, which we will launch next.

The Krona tool for interactive analysis will then open. Play around with the interactive display to understand how Krona works!

title: Where is the raw sequencing data stored publicly?
text:
Search SRA database
It‚Äôs time to put what you‚Äôve learned into practice. How about searching the SRA database yourself? Can you think of any organisms that might have been sequenced?
Let‚Äôs find out. Search for organisms you work with!

Your own search
Which organism comes to your mind? Then search for it!
Examples:

Ascovirus
Homo sapiens
Beauveria bassiana
Silkworm

Visit https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra to start your search.
Also use Krona to analyse your search!


Let‚Äôs discuss your findings!
Who found something interesing?
Can you share your findings?
